nateberkopec:
@sagivo You could also just do tests at the bottom of the file - that would be super easy to understand. Something like:

``` ruby
def my_sweet_algo
puts "oh yeah"
end

class TestMySweetAlgo < Test::Unit::TestCase

def test_sweet_algo
  assert true # or whatever
end

end
```

I'm not sure what the settings are off the top of my head, but you can make that test run automatically when you run `ruby my_sweet_algo.rb`.

I think tests could be useful for two reasons:
- When you modify the algorithm, you want to be sure it's still correct. When learning how algorithms work, I'm always modifying the code for a bunch of different reasons.
- When you modify the algorithm, you want to ensure that it's performant. [Minitest has several assertions that help you figure this out](http://madeofcode.com/posts/86-performance-benchmarking-ruby-with-minitest). I think this is very relevant to the purpose of this repo (preparation for interview questions).
. > algorithm tests are tricker since you can't really test any array to test quicksort for example and see if it runs on o(lgN). it's more just to make sure nothing breaks.

[Actually, minitest/benchmark _does_ do this](http://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-2.0/libdoc/minitest/benchmark/rdoc/MiniTest/Unit/TestCase.html#method-i-assert_performance_power)! It basically runs your code a bunch of times and plots the performance, and checks to see if you pass a statistical regression test.

It's not a formal proof, of course, but I do find it valuable.

> we can keep all the tests in one folder and the algorithms in another as long as we don't build a giant new framework monster (AKA new rails) just to show people a simple way to implement algorithms :)

I actually kind of like the tests-at-the-bottom-of-the-file approach. I'll change this PR to do that instead.
. > since the tests are all the same and look like "check if foo() == value" 

most tests look like that :grin:

the first is euclidean algorithm to calc gcd.

the extened euclidean algorithm is to calc `a`,`b` s.t `ax+by=gcd(x,y)`, it is often used to calc the modular inverse. for example, if `gcd(x,m)=1`, then the inverse of `x` modular `m` is `a` where `ax+bm=1`. it is also used for solving [linear equation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_equation) or linear congruences.
